subject: Re: Testing methods declared private
msgSnippet: Another way to test private methods is through the use of the Jtest product supplied by Parasoft.  Jtest has two methods of creating user defined test cases,
messageBody:
Another way to test private methods is through the use of the Jtest
product supplied by Parasoft. Jtest has two methods of creating user
defined test cases, one through integration with Junit, and the
second by using our symbollic test case execution. Because the latter
actually does the testing at the byte code level, it gives you the
ability to create tests that will access these private methods and
check the return values.

If you need more info, just reply or you can email me directly.

-David McCaw
ParaSoft Corporation
dmccaw@...

p.s. Jtest is a commercial tool. I hope I'm not violating any of
the user group rules by bringing it up. If I am, let me know. :-)

--- In junit@y..., Toby Ferguson <toby.h.ferguson@s...> wrote:
> Peter,
>
> private is private - so if these methods truly are private then
noone can
> get at them.
>
> However, one technique is to use an inner class that gives access
to the
> methods to be tested, and then to not include that class when
publishing the
> final code.
>
> For example, here is some class with a private method (I've
attached the
> classes too, in case this gets garbled as text)
>
> public class PrivateMethod
> {
> private String value = "foo";
>
> private String getValue(){
> return value;
> }
>
> private void setValue(String v){
> this.value = v;
> }
>
> public class Test
> {
> public String getValue(){
> return value;
> }
> public void setValue(String v){
> value = v;
> }
> }
> }
> Note the inner "Test" class exposing public versions of the private
get/set
> methods ...
>
> Here's a TestPrivateMethod class which will show how to use the
inner
> PrivateMethod.Test class:
>
> import junit.framework.TestCase;
> import junit.framework.TestSuite;
> import junit.textui.TestRunner;
>
> public class TestPrivateMethod extends TestCase
> {
>
> public TestPrivateMethod(String name){
> super(name);
> }
>
> public static void main(String [] args){
> TestRunner.run(new TestSuite(TestPrivateMethod.class));
> }
>
> /** Will not compile!
> public void testPrivateGet(){
> PrivateMethod p = new PrivateMethod();
> assertEquals(p.getValue(), "foo");
> }
> */
>
> public void testPrivateGetViaInnerClass(){
> PrivateMethod p = new PrivateMethod();
> PrivateMethod.Test pt = p.new Test();
> assertEquals("foo", pt.getValue());
> }
>
> public void testPrivateSetViaInnerClass(){
> PrivateMethod p = new PrivateMethod();
> PrivateMethod.Test pt = p.new Test();
> final String nv = "new value";
> pt.setValue(nv);
> assertEquals( nv, pt.getValue());
> }
> }
>
>
>
> p_d_w_219 wrote:
>
> > The methods that I most want to test are often the ones I want to
> > declare as private. That makes them inaccessible to my testing
> > harness.
> >
> > I could be designing my classes improperly for use with JUnit or
> > perhaps I'm setting JUnit up incorrectly. Could anyone offer me so
> > guidance on this issue.
> >
